question.title: Can I override object with sun.misc.Unsafe?

node.contents: What do you mean by "override"? Please provide more context.

astNode.text: What do you mean by "override"? Please provide more context.

node.contents: I suspect he wants a Java version of Smalltalk's [become:](http://gbracha.blogspot.com/2009/07/miracle-of-become.html).

astNode.text: I suspect he wants a Java version of Smalltalk's [become:](http://gbracha.blogspot.com/2009/07/miracle-of-become.html).

node.contents: Can I override one obejct with another if they are instance of same class, their size is the same, using sun.misc.Unsafe?

astNode.text: Can I override one obejct with another if they are instance of same class, their size is the same, using sun.misc.Unsafe?

node.contents: edit: By "override" I mean to "delete" first object, ant to fill the memory with the second one. Is it possible?

astNode.text: edit: By "override" I mean to "delete" first object, ant to fill the memory with the second one. Is it possible?

node.contents: Expanding on this solution, if you have control over the class in question you can probably solve this more elegantly by using the proxy pattern (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proxy_pattern). The proxy class would provide all the methods the actual class, but it would only delegate them to a wrapped object. Clients need not be aware if they are using a proxy, and by exchanging the wrapped object you can make it appear to them as if the object they are using was replaced.

astNode.text: Expanding on this solution, if you have control over the class in question you can probably solve this more elegantly by using the proxy pattern (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proxy_pattern). The proxy class would provide all the methods the actual class, but it would only delegate them to a wrapped object. Clients need not be aware if they are using a proxy, and by exchanging the wrapped object you can make it appear to them as if the object they are using was replaced.

node.contents: So true, proxy pattern is surely more appropriate than multiple static variables when you have multiple references to modify "at once". It is easier to modify it in the proxy class...

astNode.text: So true, proxy pattern is surely more appropriate than multiple static variables when you have multiple references to modify "at once". It is easier to modify it in the proxy class...

node.contents: By "override" I mean to "delete" first object, ant to fill the memory with the second one. Is it possible?

astNode.text: By "override" I mean to "delete" first object, ant to fill the memory with the second one. Is it possible?

node.contents: Yes - If you allocate some memory with Unsafe and write a long, then write another long in it (for example), then yes, you have deleted the first object and filled the memory with a second object. This is similar to what you can do with ByteBuffer. Of course, long is a primitive type, so it is probably not what you mean by 'object'.

astNode.text: Yes - If you allocate some memory with Unsafe and write a long, then write another long in it (for example), then yes, you have deleted the first object and filled the memory with a second object. This is similar to what you can do with ByteBuffer. Of course, long is a primitive type, so it is probably not what you mean by 'object'.

node.contents: Java allows this, because it has the control on allocated memory.

astNode.text: Java allows this, because it has the control on allocated memory.

node.contents: No - Java works with references to objects and only provides references to these objects. Moreover, it tends to move objects around in memory (i.e., for garbage collection).

astNode.text: No - Java works with references to objects and only provides references to these objects. Moreover, it tends to move objects around in memory (i.e., for garbage collection).

node.contents: There is no way to get the 'physical address' and move memory content from one object address to another, if that's what you are trying. Moreover, you can't actually 'delete' the object, because it may be referenced from elsewhere in the code.

astNode.text: There is no way to get the 'physical address' and move memory content from one object address to another, if that's what you are trying. Moreover, you can't actually 'delete' the object, because it may be referenced from elsewhere in the code.

node.contents: However, there is always the possibility of having reference A point to another objectB instead of objectA with A = objectB; You can even make this atomic with Unsafe.compareAndSwapObject(...).

astNode.text: However, there is always the possibility of having reference A point to another objectB instead of objectA with A = objectB; You can even make this atomic with Unsafe.compareAndSwapObject(...).

node.contents: Workaround - Now, let's imagine that reference A1, A2, A3 point to the same objectA. If you want all of them to suddently point to objectB, you can't use Unsafe.compareAndSwapObject(...), because only A1 would point to objectB, while A2 and A3 would still point to objectA. It would not be atomic.

astNode.text: Workaround - Now, let's imagine that reference A1, A2, A3 point to the same objectA. If you want all of them to suddently point to objectB, you can't use Unsafe.compareAndSwapObject(...), because only A1 would point to objectB, while A2 and A3 would still point to objectA. It would not be atomic.

elements.contents: public class AtomicReferenceChange { public static Object myReference = new Object(); public static void changeObject(Object newObject) { myReference = newObject; } public static void main(String[] args) { System.out.println(AtomicReferenceChange.myReference); AtomicReferenceChange.changeObject("333"); System.out.println(AtomicReferenceChange.myReference); } }

units.rawText: public class AtomicReferenceChange { public static Object myReference = new Object(); public static void changeObject(Object newObject) { myReference = newObject; } public static void main(String[] args) { System.out.println(AtomicReferenceChange.myReference); AtomicReferenceChange.changeObject("333"); System.out.println(AtomicReferenceChange.myReference); } }

node.contents: Instead of having multiple references to the same object, you could define a public static reference and have your code use AtomicReferenceChange.myReference everywhere. If you want to change the referenced object atomically, use the static method changeObject(...).

astNode.text: Instead of having multiple references to the same object, you could define a public static reference and have your code use AtomicReferenceChange.myReference everywhere. If you want to change the referenced object atomically, use the static method changeObject(...).
